This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Sues for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Adem. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinsi) el Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

ESTABLISHED 1880
Editor and Manager - - R. Swelling

SATURDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1906

div.head: British Commercial Travellers
div.p: Visiting Cairo should arrange with
" THE COMMERCIAL BUREAU "
"Sharia Madabegh, for introduction to Firms
The Plague.
Today's plague bulletin reports one recovery in Alexandria hospital.
Ghizeh Mods.
The drainage of "hods" in the Moudinieh of Ghizeh will begin early next month.
K. Y. C.
The closing cruise of the Khedivial Yachting Club will be held to-morrow afternoon," when it is hoped a large number of yachts will turn out.
The Reconnaissance March.
The laniskilling Dragoons arrived at Samanond yesterday and are to-day marching to Mahalla, and from there they will continue to Tantah.
Nile Irrigation.
Mr. K. Verschoyle, C.M.G., Inspector-General of Irrigation, contributes an article to the "Graphic" of the 13th inst. on the Nile irrigation of to-day.
Sudan Irrigation.
Mr. Dapais, Inspector-General of Irrigation in the Sudan, leaves Cairo on November 7. During his stay at the Capital he will complete his staff, which is to number from thirty to forty employés.
Seizure of Hashish.
The Suez coastguards arrested a native the day before yesterday attempting to smuggle hashish through to Cairo. A quantity of the drag was found when the man's house was searched by the police.
Alhambra Theatre,
Cicerone's comedy La Statua di Carne is to be staged at the Alhambra Theatre this evening, and to-morrow Le Grand Hotel Perroquet will be given as a matinée and Sardon's drama Patria in the evening.
Wakfs Revenue.

The revenue of the Wakt Administration from January 1 to September 30 was L.E. 203,810, and the expenditure L, E. 215,035, as against L.E. 183,562 and L.E 173,224 respectively for the same period last year.
The Late M. F. Suares.

The bronze bust of the late lamented Félix Saares will be unveiled in the middle of next month in the porch of the Italian Hospital, Cairo. The estimated cost of the bust is £68, of which £37 has been already subscribed.
Covernment Employes.

Lord Edward Cecil Pasha's Commission has a ked the various Departments and Administrations of State for lists of those employés not on the permanent staff-and this probably with a view to permanently appointing them.
Provincial Changes..

The Ministry of the Interior has decided to retire upon pension Yassin Bey Mustapha, Mundir of Keneh. It is probable that he will be succeeded by Tapha Bey Maher, Moudir of Minieh, in which case Khalil Nail Bey will be transferred from Ghizeh to Minieh.
Hashish Den Raided,

Bishara Eff. Nashi, moawin of the Menshieh Caracol, made a raid the other night on a hashish den in Anastassi-street, belonging to a Greek, named Antonio Golgoratis, where he discovered a quantity of hashish, etc. The proprietor is to be tried before the Mixed Courts on the 29th inst.
Suez Canal.

On the 25th October, 15 vessels, of which 10 were northward and 5 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 400.455.54. 7 were British, 6 German, 1 Dutch and 1 French. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 7,034,754.48, and during that time 259 vessels transited the Canal, 118 being northward, and 141 southward bound.
The Tourist Season.

The Hamburg American liner Oceana (ex Scot), Captain Mayer, arrived at Alexandria from Naples this morning with 316 first-class passengers, mostly tourists. The Oceane, which is a magnificent twin screw steamer of 9,000 tons burthen, leaves Alexandria again to-day for Naples and Genos, and will carry on a fortnightly service between these ports and Alexandria until the end of the end of the year. After that the service will be a weekly one, and will be continued by the Oceans alone. Before the passengers quitted the vessel they signed a most cordially worded testimonial to the captain for the comfort of their voyage and and the excellent arrangements of the steamer.

div.head: TANTAH AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.'

Sir, I took great trouble, and was put to much expense in order to exhibit at the recent show at Tanteh held under the auspices of the Khedivial Agricultural Society. Days and weeks have passed, and although I was informed on excellent authority that I had gained a prize I have received no notice on the subject, nor have I seen any list published in the local Press. I have a friend who is in the same position as myself. Is it not extraordinary that the Khedivial Agricultural Society should be so slack in publishing the list of prizes?
Truly Yours,
"AGRONAL"
Alexandria, 27th October.
[In reference to our correspondent's complaint we may state that we have not yet received any list of the prize, winners Ed. G.]

div.head: THE EDUCATION BILL.
div.p: IN THE HOUSE OF LORDS.
LONDON, October 26.

HOUSE OF LORDS.-The Archbishop of Canterbury, in a moderate speech, intimated his intention of moving important amendments to the Education Bill. He disclaimed any in'ention of wrecking the Bill, but he thought that. provision must be made that elementary schools should not be secularized. Religious teaching should be given by qualified teachers. Definits religions teaching, wherever possible, should be accessible to all children whose parents so desire it.
Lord Crewe declared that the Government would deal with the amendments with due respect, but that they could not abandon the principles of the majority of their fellowcountrymen. (Reuter)

div.head: LIBERAL ARMY POLICY.
div.p: TO BE DECLARED IN THE SPRING.
LONDON, October 26.

HOUSE OF COMMONS. Mr. Haldane stated that the Government would declare its army policy in the spring. It would aim specially at the cobesion of the regulars, militia, yeomanry, and volunteers so as to form a united army. (Reuter)

div.head: THE BOGUS GERMAN CAPTAIN.
div.p: AN OLD GAOL BIRD.
BERLIN, October 26.

The so called captain who effected the robbery at Koepcnick has been captured. He is & cobbler named Voig of Tilsit, who has passed 27 years in prison for offences of all kinds. He confesset everything. This enhances the mirth, mingled with atupefaction, produced in Germany by the incident. (Reuter)

div.head: EAST AFRICA PROTECTORATE.
div.p: LONDON, October 26.
An order has been gazetted erecting the Commissionership of the East Africa Protectorate into a Governorship and creating executive and legislative councils.
(Router)

div.head: POPE AND KAISER.
div.p: ROME, October 21.
The Pope received Herr von Tschirschky, who presented the Emperor William's respects. His Holiness returned his warmest greetings.
(Peuter)

div.head: AUSTRIAN RAILWAYS.
div.p: VIENNA, October 26.
The Chamber has passed a Bill authorising the State to buy back the Northern railways.
(Harvas)

div.head: COUNT GOLUCHOWSKI.
div.p: VIENNA, October 26.
The Emperor has sent an autograph letter to Count Goluchowski conferring on him the Grand Cordon of the Order of St. Etienne. (H.)

div.head: FOUNDERING OF MAIL STEAMER.
div.p: PARIS, October 26.
The mail steamer Isaac Pereira has gone ashore at Minorca. The passengers were saved.
(Havas)

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: THE NOUVEAUTES INCIDENT.

This morning Gilbert Griffith and John Lamprey appeared before H. B. M.'s Consul 1 at Cairo on a charge of being drunk and disorderly at the Nouveautés Theatre on the C might of the 21s inst. The police were represented by Mr. H. G. Archer, Mr. Had- & dleston Stokes, being Counsel for the defence. The case was adjourned at 12.45 p.m. till Mon day, the defendants being called upon to find- £50 surety on their own recognisances. A number of witnesses were heard. during the morning, among them being M. Lauri, proprietor of the theatre, M. Michel Falan Salman, a waiter named Polidis, who complained of having been assaulted by the defendants, and other employés of the theatre.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Judge Cator will probably preside at the forthcoming session at Alexandria and Cairo of His Majesty's Supreme Consular Court for the Dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte, E as Judge Pigott is due to arrive at Constantinople from leave only on the 14th November. The date of Judge Cator's arrival is still t uncertain, as it depends on a very important case that is to be tried shortly at Constanti-t nople. Probably he will arrive at Alexandria in I the latter part of November.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: TO BE REPLACED BY G.P.O.

Now that the construction of a new opera house has been finally decided or, speculation has been rife as to what the Government intends to do with the site of the present one We are in a position to state that the site will not be disposed of by the Government, to whom it belongs, but will be retained for its own use. There is a probability that the projected General Post Office-in Cairo will stand on the site of the present opera house. As soon as the latter has been demolished and the former, which is to be a huge building, has been completed, the Postal Administration will be removed to the Capital

div.head: PRINCE GEORGE AT PORT SAID.
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
Port Said, Friday..

The Danish SS. Birma reached Port Said at eight o'clock this morning, and moored in front of the Suez Canal Company's offices. She was immediately boarded by M. George Sarros,- the Hellenic Consul, accompanied by M. Psychas, acting Hellenic Diplomatic Agent, and a number of the leading members of the colony. M. Sarros, in welcoming Prince George, presented him with a magnificent bouquet, and M. Pneumaticos, on behalf of the members of the Ephory, made an appropriate speech. After taking leave of his visitors, whom he thanked very heartily for their welcome, the ex-High Commissioner, with Prince Waldemar and their companions, and M. Broatch, the Danish Consul, landed on the wharf of Messrs. Wills & Co., Ltd., and went for a drive round the town, at the end of which they held a reception in the Orthodox Greek Church of the Holy Saviour for the clergy and laity. Every- where the party were the objects of manifestations of joy on the part of the Hellenic colony. Prince George and Prince Waldemar breakfasted with M. Broatch at the Consalar residence, which was surrounded by an enthusias- tic crowd. The Prince re-embarked at 10.45, and the Birma entered the Canal at 2 p.m. M. Sarros, the Hellenic Consul, left by. the two o'clock train for Kantara to transmit to Prince George an urgent telegram, which arrived after the Birma had started. The vessel was signalled to stop, and the message was delivered on board, thanks to the courtesy of M. Dumont, Principal Agent of the Canal Company, who placed a boat at the Consul's disposal.

div.head: POST OFFICE BUDGET.
div.p: The Postal Administration has just put down its budget for the coming year at L.E. 270,000, which is an increase of about L.E. 30,000 over that of last year. The object of the extra amount asked for is to reinforce the existing staff. During the past three years the work of the post office in Egypt throughout all its branches has increased fifty per cent. As an instance of the extraordinary increase of work it is worth noting that owing to the registration fees having been reduced this year from ten to five millièmes the work of registration has increased by over forty per cent. since the 1st January.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive gave an "iftar" at Ras-el-Tin Palace yesterday evening to a large number of native notables, and afterwards returned to Montazah Palace, where he is spending the day.

div.head: BOUNDARY COMMISSION.
div.p: Mirls Owen Bey will not issue any report on his mission to Sinai. He intends, soon after the Sirdar's departare, to go to Sorrento, near Naples, for two months' well-merited holiday.

div.head: THE THEFT OF BANK NOTES.
div.p: The mystery surrounding the disappearance of National Bank notes to the value of L. B. 3,900 in the Post Office is still the subject of a rigorous enquiry. So far as is at present known none of these bank notes have been passed.

div.head: ENGLISH OPERA IN CAIRO.
div.p: "THE CATCH OF THE SEASON."

On leaving the house at the close of the performance of "The Catch of the Season," at the Khedivial Opera House, on Thursday night, our chief feeling was one of admiration for the audacity of Mr. Seymour Hicks. That a man should dare write and stage a play of that nature shows that he knew and despised his London audience to a nicety. To expect a plot is forbidden, but a libretto devoid of hamour, epigram, or even topical allusions, begins to pale very soon, and the lyrics were luckily for the most part inaudible. If a leading character is to rivet the attention of the house by a stammer, surely it were advisable to give him a witty remark to make at the end of it, and the daologue between the Duke and Dandreary in Act II, sank below the level of provincial pantomime. One only hopes that our Continental friends do not judge the English stage by a piece such as this, for however much the original production may be improved by dresses, scenery, etc., one cannot get away from the book and the music, of which the less said the better.

The first act never seemed to begin until the entry of Mr. Harry Cole and Mr. E. Attwell, who livened things up considerably, though perhaps it is a bit hard to judge the local Gibson Girls by the Camille Clifford standard. The dressing-scene at the end of the act was a fiasco, and once nearly stopped altogether, but the conductor by a barst of desperate energy managed to pull them through somehow.

Act II. was a revelation to the uninitiated of the wonderful things that can happen at a ducal ball. It was not a fancy-dress affair, but you found Miss Morra giving a Japanese song and dance not at all badly, shortly followed by a Highland fling and an Irish song, in which the patriotism of the gallery was appealed to with success. Miss Corlass was a little disappointing after her performances on her last visit. She seems to have lost some of her voice and activity, and made no real hit till her duet and dance with Mr. Cole, which was the most successful item in the play and quite deserved its applause and encore. Taken all round, the company worked really hard and made the best of a very poor job, the only person not rising to the occasion being a well-known member of the Royal Engineers.

div.head: SUBVENTIONS TO THEATRES.
div.p: "Al Mokattam," in a recently published article, replies to the critiques of several native organs which appear to object to the granting of subventions to European theatres in Egypt and to the construction of a new Opera House. According to our contemporary, these subventions are in a sense a commercial speculation. The opera attracts tourists, gives them a motive for prolonging their stay in Cairo, and thereby farthers the expenditure of considerable sums in the Capital. With this statement we agree, but when our contemporary asserts that the country receives a hundred-fold the amount of the subvention paid by Government we feel bound to hint that over-statement injures a good case. The tourist element is not as a rale conspicuous on opera-nights. We have sometimes wished it was more in evidence, for it is notorious that a goodly proportion of the habitual opera-goers of Cairo confine themselves during the entr'actes and overtures to a survey of the frocks and faces-doubtless charming-which they see around them, and subside, on the lifting of the curtain, into a comatose lethargy, only broken by the fortissimo effects of the orchestra, or by the rapturous applause with which another section of the audience - enthusiastic if ancritical-greets the high note of the tenor or the conclusion of the soprano's best known aria. Again if tourists would only frequent the opera more regularly we should hear less of those cheerful individuals, who have no ear for European music, to whom three or four notes separated by a quarter of a tone and produced from the throat are the ideal of vocal beauty, who talk gaily in Arabic through the overture of Lohengrin or Tann hauser, politely inform the remonstrant that they will cease as soon as the opera begins, and are obviously bored by all except the ballet, and scenes that represent duels, executions, or conspiracies.

In our opinion the opera is not intended to be a mere resort of the fashionable, nor to replace Karakash and the cinematograph. Nor is it -pace our excellent contemporary -a purely commercial specalation. Its object is two-fold-to instruct the musician and to please that section of the public which enjoys good music, acting, and singing. We therefore hope that when the regulations that will rule the new Opera House are known we shall find that a certain number of good places are regularly reserved for the occasional public. We do not ask for the number of abonnements to be reduced-only for such an increase of accommodation that will allow the music-lover of moderate means to indulge his hobby with more ease and, if possible, at less expense. Again, we should like to see more definiteness in the programmes. A tourist for instance who would like to see a particular opera-can never be certain that it will be given till late on the night preceding its performance. Why cannot we have proper programmes for the week not to be departed from without the cogent reasons?

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN OFFICIALS.
div.p: "AL-MOAYAD'S" DISGUST.
"Al-Moayad" writes as follows:-
Does Lord Cromer desire to posses; for his country the bricks of Egypt, or the hearts of her song?
Like the rest of Oriental nations the Egyptians are brought up to acquire habits, character, and sentiments different to those possessed by the English.

The hearts of such a nation cannot be conquered by rough and cruel treatment, unless the governing power means to be absolute and unjust, of which attributes the English absolve themselves, declaring that, of all nations they are the most disposed to kindness, and the best for developing colonies. The Egyptian nation, whose habits and character differ from those of the English, cannot have those habits and that character altered just as if they were its frontiers or streets; but the English can win the love of that nation by kindly treatment, and so become masters of human hearts, instead of satisfying themselves with bricks.

The most important thing we wish Lord Cromer to attend to is that he should make the English officials understand that they are workers, and not masters, official, serving the country from which they receive pay, and not gods, to be worshipped.

I have no doubt Lord Cromer has learnt the causes of the discontent of Eastern Nations with the English at the same time that these Orientals mix happily with other Europeans. This, however, is easily seen when we contrast the courtesy shown by the official, merchant, and workman of France with English arrogance. Lord Cromer should see that it is much wiser to try and cultivate among the English officials in Egypt that courtesy which will not fail to attract the Egyptian, who will then obey willingly and not through fear.

The other thing that the nation expects from the wisdom of Lord Cromer is that, if be insists on giving the high offices to Englishmen he should select those officials from among experienced and middle-aged or old men, who are free from the impetuosity and stubborness of youth.
Such men will have good influence over the natives, and will give the cffices which they fill an air of grandeur and supremacy, and preserve these offices from the faults of youth..

Lord Cromer knows perfectly that the English nation, though far advanced in civilization and general cultare, still makes the judges of her courts wear white wigs, in order that those who stand before them feel that they are in the presence of old man. The object of this is to have their people impressed with the solemnity of old age, which has always been known to influence people.

Lord Cromer knows that Eastern nations, and specially Mohamedans, reverence old age more than any other nations do for the very simple reason that the human mind submits to the dictates of experience. Why, then, are the highest offices in the Egyptian Government given to young men who are still' in the first phase of life, and who begin, in Egypt, the country they have to promote, to learn how to become politicians, masters, and governors.
Let Lord Cromer fancy the members of the Egyptian Legi lative Council-all of them aged and experienced men-asking the advice of one of the Advisers or bidding him adien at a railway station.

Let Lord Cromer picture to himself, bearing in mind the habits and character of the nation, whether it is not disgusting to see ten of the most noted of her people, men that represent the nation, the youngest of them more than fifty years old-all standing before a youth who has just left school.

Let him ask himself whether it is not disgusting to see grey haired men in fall dress which they use on meeting the Khedive, surrounding the young inspector who stands amongst them in his white linen suit, with the edges of his trousers turned up as if he had been wading in sakiehs, and wearing his straw hat and holding his pipe in his mouth, and it may be his dog follows him.

We do not say that youth may not be wise and intelligent, but we say the colonizing power that wishes to possess the hearts of the people her colonies hould use experienced officials and should also respect as much as possible the habits of these latter nations.

div.head: NEW ANCHOR LINER.
div.p: The new steamer Castalia, built by Messrs. Barclay, Carle & Co. (Limited), Whiteinch, for the Indian service of the Anchor Line, carried out her trial trip on the Firth of Clyde recently, when, on the invitation of the owners and builders, about eighty ladies and gentlemen were on board. The weath r was dull and hazy, but the rain held off, and the cruise was much enjoyed. After leaving Gourock, the vessel proceeded at once to the measured mile at Skelmorlie, where, on a double run, she attained a mean speed of 141 knots, the indicated horse-power being 4599.5 The Castalia which has a gross tonnage of 6,200 tons, and a deadweight capacity of 8,600 tons, has been built to the highest class of the British Corporation. On the bridge and promenade decks superior accommodation has been provided for ninety first-class passengers in large and airy two and four berth state rooms. There is also a spacious saloon, as well as a musicroom, and nursery. Excellent arrangements have been made for cargo. The 'tween decke are unusually lofty, being 10 feet in height. There are ten powerful steam winches.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Cromer, after lunching with Mr. and Mrs. Gould at the British Consulate yesterday, drove to Ras el-Tin Palace, and had an audience of the Khedive at 3 p.m., returning to Cairo by the 4.25 train.
Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, the Sirdar, who came down from Cairo yesterday and was granted an audience of the Khedive, returned to the Capital at noon.
The "Minbar" has it that Ibrahim Pasha Fethi, head of the Egyptian Commission for the delimitation the Sinaïtio frontier, is to be appointed moudir of an important province in Lower Egypt.
Mr. A. V. Thomson, Director in Egypt of the Standard Life Insurance Company, and Mrs. Thomson, have arrived in Cairo from. Europe.
Mr. Pittock, of the Eastern Telegraph Company at Saez, was married this morning at the British Consulate, Alexandria, to Miss Gladys Williams, of Ramleh.
M. Cambon, junt., after a brief stay at the French Diplomatis Agency, left Cairo for Alexandria yesterday by the 9.30 a.m. train.

Among the passengers by the S.S. Oceana, which arrived at Alexandria this morning were Coles Pasha, Nangovich Bey, John Bey Haicalie, Mr. Constantine Meimarachi, Mr. Sinadino, Mr. Astley B. Friend, Mr. Robino, Capt. Duffres, Mr. O. Bracha, Mr. Gast. Suares, Mr. 8. Wild, Mr. J. Rolo, Mrs. Charles Baer, and Mr. Chalon.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAY COMPANY.
div.p: The shareholders of this company held their ordinary annual general meeting at Brussels on the 17th inst. We publish the profit and loss account on page 6 of to-day's issue. The company has had a very successful year under the able management of M. Dessales d'Epinoix.

The principal works which were began by the company during the period covered by the report include the corstrnotion of thenew Gam rah line, and the extension of the Saptieh and Shopbra lines. The line from Ghizeh to join that to the Pyramids cannot be laid until. the Rodah bridge has been finished. The dew central generating works are proceeding most satisfactory, and the fi st turbo-dynamo of 1,500 kw. is already set up. The receipts from the tramways show an increase of 872,523 18 francs over 1905, and the boat receipts an increase of 13,802.44 franos.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MUMMIFYING.
div.p: TO BE FOLLOWED IN AMERICA.

"Before many years all dead bodies will beembalmed after the custom of the ancient Egyptians, and, not only that, but the laws of the states will compel the embalming of all bodies," said H. F. Camerford, a Cininnati agent for an embalming fluid, at the Blatz-hotel. Mr. Camerford was one of the demonstrators before a recent convention of funeral directors.

"I have a body in my house which has remained perfect for fourteen years under the action of embalming flaid," continued Mr. Cumerford. "The liquid now used is far better than that made by the Egyptians, for it preserves the body without mutilation, brings a healthy look to the features, and actually makes some people look better after they are dead than when they lived.

"But the health of the living is more to be considered than the looks of the dead, and the advantages of embalming flaid as a preventive of disease are what will bring it into general use. Ninety per cent. of contagious disease is communicated to the living from the bodies of the dead. Germs which have caused death multiply a thousand fold in a corpse and thereby endanger the lives of all who come near. Many people get diseases at funerals and never have the least ides where these maladies were contracted. It is well-known now by medical men that the mere fact of exposure does not assure the exposed person of an attack. A person in good health may be exposed many times without harm, but the germs obtain a foothold in a system which chances to be in a susceptible condition. So it is that a friend may contract a disease at a faneral while those in the household escape.

"Nearly all undertakers are, nowadays, embalmers. The interest of undertakers in obtaining certificates from the state so that they may legally do such work was evidenced by more than 100 who took the state examination a few weeks ago. Nearly all states forbid embalming without a license. Among the regulations of burial which I expect to see discussed in legislatures in the near future is one that no body shall be buried unless embalmed, but that all shall be subjected to the preserving liquid as soon as death arrives. "In some localities about 50 per cent. of bodies are now embalmed."

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
